Detailed Description

Reads data from a BinData instance and pushes it towards a remote OPP server.

This class offers a simplified asynchronous interface to applications which need to act as an OBEX OPP (Object Push Profile) client.

Concept:
Users must subclass ObexOppBinDataPushClient and implement the abstract method OnPushComplete() to get notified when an ongoing operation is completed. An object PUSH operation is initiated by calling Push() and submitting an instance of an class derived from the BinData interface class. Data is then automatically read from the user-supplied BinData object and transmitted to the remote OPP server chunk by chunk. While the procedure is running, the ObexOppBinDataPushClient instance is busy and will not accept another call to Push(). An ongoing operation may be cancelled by calling Abort().

In any case, OnPushComplete() is called at the end of the asynchronous procedure and indicates either success (good ObexResult) or failure. When the operation was rejected or cancelled by the remote server, the remote server's OBEX response code and optional DESCRIPTION header are also available to the user. After OnPushComplete() has been invoked, the ObexOppBinDataPushClient instance is ready for the next PUSH operation.

Since ObexOppBinDataPushClient is derived from ObexOppClient, multiple instances share a single OPP protocol implementation for all transports. When Push() is called on a ObexOppBinDataPushClient instance while another one is already active, the PUSH operation is queued until the protocol implementation becomes available again, then automatically resumed. Each ObexOppBinDataPushClient can hold exactly one PUSH request.

Member Enumeration Documentation

anonymous enum
 

Application data fragment size.

Data is transferred between application layer and Transport Adapter using an internal buffer, whose size affects performance. When this value is chosen to low, message load will increase, forcing the protocol stack to wait for the application layer most of the time. When chosen too high, individual operations might last too long, especially copying of memory blocks which will decrease system responsiveness and also require more memory for buffering.

Enumerator:
DefFragSize  Default fragment size.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Default constructor.

Default-constructed instances must be initialized using Init() before using them the first time.

ObexOppBinDataPushClient::ObexOppBinDataPushClient (  ExecutionContext *  ctx_ptr  ) 
 

Constructor. Constructs a usable object instance.

Intended to be used with dynamically allocated objects (new). Hint: Avoid using new() - if you can, allocate instances statically.

Parameters:
ctx_ptr Execution context to be used by the client, for example an application pointer. You may pass '0' as actual parameter to specify the currently active context, which must be valid at the time Init() is called.

Member Function Documentation

ObexResult ObexOppBinDataPushClient::Abort (  const WString &  desc,
BOOLEAN  force_sync = FALSE
) 
 

Aborts a pending PUSH or PULL operation.

After the pending operation has been aborted, OnPushComplete() is invoked with an ObexResult indication that the operation was aborted. A different behaviour can be achieved by setting 'force_sync' to 'TRUE', this will terminate any pending operation synchronously from the API point of view. This behaviour might be useful when sudden application shutdown must be dealt with.

Parameters:
desc Textual description of the abort cause.
force_sync Force synchronous ABORT, this means that on return from the call any BinData instance is no longer referenced and can be destroyed and OnPushComplete() will NOT be invoked.

Reimplemented from ObexOppClient.

void ObexOppBinDataPushClient::OnPushComplete (  ObexResult  result,
ObexObject::ResponseCode  resp_code,
const WString &  push_desc
)  [protected, virtual]
 

Indicates completion of a PUSH operation.

Completion of an operation does not necessarily mean success. Check the result parameter to find out whether an operation terminated successfully or not.

Caution:
Don't forget to call the base classes' implementation of this method from your overridden one. This should be the first statement of your implementation.

Example:

            class MyObexOppBinDataPushClient : public ObexOppBinDataPushClient {
                public:
                    // Your stuff ...

                protected:
                    virtual void OnPushComplete(ObexResult                  result,
                                                ObexObject::ResponseCode    resp_code,
                                                const WString &             push_desc);
                private:
                    typedef ObexOppBinDataPushClient    Base;
                    // Your stuff ...
            };

            void MyObexOppBinDataPushClient::OnPushComplete(ObexResult                  result,
                                                            ObexObject::ResponseCode    resp_code,
                                                            const WString &             push_desc)
            {
                // Notify base-class implementation
                Base::OnPushComplete(result, resp_code, push_desc);

                // Your stuff - notify application etc.
            }

Parameters:
result Either indicates success or carries an error code (for example, 'OperationAborted').
resp_code Contains the OBEX response code returned by the remote server. Particularly interesting when result equals 'ObexError' ...
push_desc Contains the description if one was returned by the remote server.

Reimplemented from ObexOppClient.

ObexResult ObexOppBinDataPushClient::Push (  const String &  obex_url,
BinData *  obj_src_ptr,
MimeType  obj_type,
const WString &  obj_name,
const WString &  obj_desc = L""
) 
 

Initiates pushing an object towards a remote OPP server.

Parameters:
obex_url URL of the OBEX transport to use.
obj_src_ptr Pointer to an instance of a class derived from APOXI BinData.
obj_type Mime type of the object to be transferred. Will be encoded as an OBEX TYPE header. Must be known by MimeTypeTable class !
obj_name Name of the OBEX object name to be transferred. Will be encoded as an OBEX NAME header.
obj_desc Description of the object to be transferred. When provided, it will be encoded as an OBEX DESCRIPTION header.
Returns:
ObexResult which evaluates to 'TRUE' when the operation has been started, 'FALSE' otherwise.
